data.title: Last Name: Meaning, Origin & Family History
data.meta_description: 68.8% Ashkenazi Jewish origin. 98.2% White in US. Jewish (from Belarus and Lithuania): variant of Horowitz, originating under Russian influence, since Russian.
data.text:
How common is the last name Gurevich in the United States?

According to the Decennial U.S. Census, the surname Gurevich has seen a rise in popularity over the years. In 2000, it was ranked 22,258th and by 2010, it had moved up to the 21,371st position, indicating a positive change of approximately 4%. The number of people with the surname also increased from 1,081 in 2000 to 1,225 in 2010, marking a growth of over 13%. Additionally, the proportion of people with the Gurevich surname per 100,000 increased by 5% over the decade.

Race and Ethnicity of people with the last name Gurevich

The data from the Decennial U.S. Census also provides us with an insight into the ethnicity of individuals bearing the Gurevich surname. As of 2010, the majority of them identified as White, accounting for about 98.20%, which was an increase of 1.39% from 2000. There was a minor decrease in the percentage identifying as Hispanic, dropping from 1.20% in 2000 to 1.14% in 2010. The proportion identifying with two or more ethnicities decreased to zero by 2010 from 1.76% in 2000. No significant representation from Asian/Pacific Islander, Black, or American Indian and Alaskan Native communities was recorded for this surname in either census year.

Gurevich ancestry composition

23andMe computes an ancestry breakdown for each customer. People may have ancestry from just one population or they may have ancestry from several populations. The most commonly-observed ancestry found in people with the surname Gurevich is Ashkenazi Jewish, which comprises 68.8% of all ancestry found in people with the surname. The next two most common ancestries are Eastern European (19.4%) and British & Irish (2.6%). Additional ancestries include French & German, Iranian, Caucasian & Mesopotamian, Greek & Balkan, Scandinavian, and Japanese.

Ready to learn more about your ancestry? Get the most comprehensive ancestry breakdown on the market by taking our DNA test. Shop 23andMe

Possible origins of the surname Gurevich

Your DNA provides clues about where your recent ancestors may have lived. Having many distant relatives in the same location suggests that you may all share common ancestry there. Locations with many distant relatives can also be places where people have migrated recently, such as large cities. If a large number of individuals who share your surname have distant relatives in a specific area, it could indicate a connection between your surname and that location, stemming from either recent ancestral ties or migration.

Based on 23andMe data, people with last name Gurevich have recent ancestry locations spanning a few countries, mostly in Poland, and Russia.

RECENT ANCESTRY LocationPercentageLesser Poland Voivodeship , Poland42.30 %Masovian Voivodeship , Poland40.80 %Podkarpackie Voivodeship , Poland40.80 %Podlaskie Voivodeship , Poland39.40 %Moscow Oblast , Russian Federation39.40 %

Your paternal lineage may be linked to the Cham

One of the many populations harboring members of haplogroup O1b1a1a1a1 is the Cham ethnic group, a group of people who speak Austronesian languages in Mainland Southeast Asia. Austronesian languages make up a language family that is extremely large and widespread, comprising over 350 million people on islands such as Madagascar, Easter Island, and many others. However, Austronesian languages are less common on mainland Asia, with a notable exception being the Chamic language. Research suggests that ancestors of the Cham people migrated from Southeast Asian islands to the mainland around the year 500 BCE, and that early Cham populations quickly began mixing with indigenous southern Vietnamese populations. As a result, the Chamic language now has words that were borrowed from languages spoken by indigenous Vietnamese people. It is likely that an ancestral Kinh population was one of the populations that mixed with the Cham people shortly after their migration to mainland Asia.

Your maternal lineage may be linked to Marie Antoinette

Because it is so dominant in the general European population, haplogroup H also appears quite frequently in the continent's royal houses. Marie Antoinette, an Austrian Hapsburg who married into the French royal family, inherited the haplogroup from her maternal ancestors. So did Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, whose recorded genealogy traces his female line to Bavaria. Scientists also discovered that famed 16th century astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus traced his maternal lineages to haplogroup H.
